title: Hans Rothfels
text:
Hans Rothfels (12 April 1891 – 22 June 1976) was a German <a href="nationalist">nationalist</a> <a href="conservatism">conservative</a> <a href="historian">historian</a>. He supported an idea of authoritarian German state, dominance of Germany over Europe and was hostile to Germany's eastern neighbours. After his applications for honorary Aryan status were rejected, due to his Jewish ancestry and increased persecution of Jewish people by Nazis, he was forced to emigrate to the United Kingdom and later to the United States during the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>, after which he became opposed to the Nazi regime. Rothfels returned to <a href="West%20Germany">West Germany</a> after 1945 where he continued to influence history teaching and became an influential figure among West German scholars.
Biography.
Rothfels was born to a wealthy <a href="Jewish">Jewish</a> family in <a href="Kassel">Kassel</a>, <a href="Hesse-Nassau">Hesse-Nassau</a>. In 1910, he converted to <a href="Lutheranism">Lutheranism</a>. He was studying history and philosophy at <a href="Heidelberg%20University">Heidelberg University</a> when <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> broke out in 1914. As a student, Rothfels had been a leading pupil of <a href="Friedrich%20Meinecke">Friedrich Meinecke</a>. Rothfels served in the <a href="German%20Army%20%28German%20Empire%29">German Army</a> as a reserve officer and was badly wounded near <a href="Soissons">Soissons</a>. He lost one of his legs and was in a hospital until 1917. He was awarded the <a href="Iron%20Cross">Iron Cross</a>, Second Class. In 1918, Rothfels's dissertation on <a href="Carl%20von%20Clausewitz">Carl von Clausewitz</a>, "Carl von Clausewitz: Politik und Krieg", led to Heidelberg granting him a degree in History. In 1920, Rothfels's dissertation was published as a book. In 1922, he edited and published a collection of Clausewitz's private letters. In addition, Rothfels published several collections of <a href="Otto%20von%20Bismarck">Otto von Bismarck</a>'s letters, and was the first historian to be authorized by the Bismarck family to publish the Iron Chancellor's correspondence. Rothfels was noted for his claim that Bismarck was neither the "iron chancellor" of "banal legend" nor an "opportunist", but rather a profoundly religious man struggling to deal with a reality whose full complexity was only understandable to God. He defended Bismarck's Germanization policies against Poles claiming they were "defensive".
Between 1924 and 1926, Rothfels taught at the <a href="University%20of%20Berlin">University of Berlin</a>. From 1926 to 1934, he worked as a professor, holding the Chair of History at the <a href="University%20of%20K%C3%B6nigsberg">University of Königsberg</a>. During his time in <a href="K%C3%B6nigsberg">Königsberg</a>, he was well known for his highly nationalistic interpretation of German history. A <a href="reactionary">reactionary</a> in his politics, Rothfels was hostile towards the <a href="Weimar%20Republic">Weimar Republic</a>, through combination of authoritarianism and mass national movement, he hoped, it would be destroyed, and connections with Western democracies broken, and envisioned that on ruins of this state a new Reich would emerged formed out of East Prussian Baltic Northeast and Southeastern outposts of former <a href="Habsburg%20Monarchy">Habsburg Empire</a>. In foreign affairs, he often denounced the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Versailles">Treaty of Versailles</a> and the eastern borders it had imposed on Germany. Rothfels advocated German domination of Eastern Europe and making its population into serfs. As a historian, his major interests were <a href="Otto%20von%20Bismarck">Otto von Bismarck</a>, Clausewitz, and later on, the conservative German opposition to <a href="Adolf%20Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a>. A major interest of Rothfels in the 1920s was his belief in the obsolescence of the nation-state, and the need for a "loosening up" of the Versailles borders through increased protection of minorities. Rothfels promoted an idea of race classification based on readiness of non-German ethnic groups in Eastern Europe to submit themselves to rule of German Third Reich The Eastern and Southeastern nationalities were to be "restructured" and integrated with German "<a href="master%20race">master race</a>". Non-Germans would have been subject to hierarchical employment conditions and essentially have status of <a href="indentured">indentured</a> workers, based on racist criteria Those living outside the "German sphere" were to be classified by hierarchy based on their "cultural heritage" and ruled under direction of Germans and a vassal class that would collaborate with them.
Although supportive of right-wing politics (according to some, he might have voted for <a href="Hitler">Hitler</a> in 1932), he was subject to increasing persecution, being <a href="Jew">Jew</a>ish by birth. Eventually, Rothfels was forced to leave his university position due to his Jewish ancestry, despite intervention by <a href="Hermann%20Rauschning">Hermann Rauschning</a>, the Nazi president of Danzig Senate, and <a href="Theodor%20Oberlander">Theodor Oberlander</a>, director of <a href="Bund%20Deutscher%20Osten">League of German East</a> (Bund der Deutschen Osten) and NSDAP's East Prussian intelligence agency, and was forbidden to teach a year later. While Rothfels tried to get an honorary Aryan status with support by <a href="Joachim%20von%20Ribbentrop">Joachim von Ribbentrop</a>, his efforts were fruitless. Subject to increasing persecution and discrimination by the State, he reluctantly left <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Germany</a> in 1938 for the United Kingdom. What decided the issue for him was his experience during the <a href="Kristallnacht">Kristallnacht</a> <a href="pogrom">pogrom</a> when his house was looted and trashed by the <a href="Sturmabteilung">SA</a> and he himself was arrested and held by the <a href="Gestapo">Gestapo</a> for several hours, during which he was deprived of his crutches and beaten up. Together with his wife and their three children, Rothfels left for the United Kingdom, where he hastily began to learn <a href="English%20language">English</a>, a language that he subsequently mastered.
Exile.
After teaching at <a href="St%20John%27s%20College%2C%20Oxford">St. John's College</a>, <a href="University%20of%20Oxford">Oxford</a> from 1938 to 1940, Rothfels was interned on the <a href="Isle%20of%20Man">Isle of Man</a>. During this time his only known publication was an essay from 1940 in which he discussed Soviet and German interaction in the <a href="Baltics">Baltics</a>. Rothfels defended German hegemony over this "outpost of Western Europe and Western civilization" and complained about resettlement of Germans there due to Soviet-Nazi treaties. Rothfels left for the United States, where he stayed until 1951, and took U.S. citizenship. He taught at <a href="Brown%20University">Brown University</a> in <a href="Providence%2C%20Rhode%20Island">Providence</a>, <a href="Rhode%20Island">Rhode Island</a> and at the <a href="University%20of%20Chicago">University of Chicago</a> in <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>, <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a> where he became a professor. Considering his views at that time, a Jewish-German student was surprised that Rothfels was forced to leave Germany in the first place. During his time in the United States, he befriended the American publisher <a href="Henry%20Regnery">Henry Regnery</a> and became actively involved in the <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican Party</a>.
In an essay published in 1943, in the book "The Makers of Modern Strategy" on Clausewitz, has been praised by <a href="Michael%20Howard%20%28historian%29">Michael Howard</a> as the first serious essay ever published on Clausewitz in <a href="English%20language">English</a>. In his essay, Rothfels argued that Clausewitz's military theories were more sophisticated than the "Mahdi of Mass" interpretation of Clausewitz that had been popularized by such historians as Sir <a href="Basil%20Liddell%20Hart">Basil Liddell Hart</a>. Rothfels argued that it was inappropriate to view Clausewitz in the context of later events; instead Rothfels insisted on understanding Clausewitz and his theory of war in the context of the <a href="Napoleonic%20Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a> and on understanding the Clausewitz the man as the key to understanding Clausewitz the military thinker. Rothfels maintained Clausewitz's personality, social background, war experience, and his schooling all needed to be understood to properly appreciate his theories about war. Most notably, Rothfels portrayed Clausewitz as a man under considerable psychological strain caused by his commoner background in the largely aristocratic Prussian Army. Through Rothfels contended that aspects of "<a href="Vom%20Krieg">Vom Krieg</a>" were outdated due to advances in military technology and tactics, nonetheless, Rothfels felt that Clausewitz was the most important military philosopher of all time. The U.S. military historian <a href="Peter%20Paret">Peter Paret</a> has differed with some of Rothfels's interpretation of Clausewitz, but acknowledged Rothfels as a major influence on his work on Clausewitz.
In 1948, Rothfels published his most famous book, "The German Opposition To Hitler", which celebrated those conservatives who attempted the <a href="20%20July%20plot">20 July plot</a> of 1944, which was based upon a lecture given at the University of Chicago in 1947. Rothfels, who remained a steadfast German nationalist all his life, saw the conspirators against the <a href="National%20Socialist%20German%20Workers%20Party">National Socialist</a> regime as representative of all that was best about German life and argued that the actions of the conspirators had restored Germany's honour from the disgrace the Nazis had brought upon it. Rothfels accepted <a href="Edmund%20Burke">Edmund Burke</a>'s idea that the best defenders of liberty come from the upper crust of society and cast the men and women of 20 July as a perfect example of Burke's theory. Rothfels claimed that the German opposition was motivated by the highest possible ethical and moral considerations, and asserted that there were no self-interested motives whatsoever amongst the men and women of the 20 July. Rothfels argued that the actions of the 20 July conspirators were motivated a sense of "noblesse oblige", devotion to the principles of <a href="Christianity">Christianity</a> and the highest form of <a href="patriotism">patriotism</a>. Rothfels was fond of pointing out the difficulties involved in attempting to overthrow one's government in war-time, which in Rothfels view, was a sign of the true patriotism of the 20 July conspirators.
Rothfels saw Nazism as a type of <a href="totalitarianism">totalitarianism</a>, and often argued that there was no moral difference between <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a> and the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>; in his view, the <a href="Cold%20War">Cold War</a> was merely a continuation of the struggle between what he called the "conservative freedom movement" and totalitarian forces. In particular, Rothfels was opposed to any sort of "<a href="Sonderweg">Sonderweg</a>" interpretation of <a href="History%20of%20Germany">German history</a>, and argued that <a href="Nazism">Nazism</a> was the result of the general problems of modern civilization, which Rothfels saw as based on a set of values that were overtly materialistic, secular, and dehumanizing, and which had reduced most people to a mindless mass. Rothfels wrote "In many respects, Nationals can be considered as the final summit of an extreme consequence of the secularization movement of the nineteenth century". In Rothfels's view, the values of modern mass civilization had led most people to forget the fundamental values of <a href="Western%20culture">the West</a>, which in his opinion were based on respect for <a href="God">God</a> and the individual. Rothfels argued that "Modern mass civilization generates a reservoir of evil forces whose release spells barbarism...What triumphed after the pseudo-legal revolution of 1933 was in fact and to a great extent the dark forces forming the sedimment of every modern society". Rothfels argued that the Nazis came to power as a result of a series of unfortunate developments that had occurred in "Germany" after World War I such as the Great Inflation of 1923 and the <a href="Great%20Depression">Great Depression</a>, and often criticized those in his view promoted the view that sought to equate "Deutschum" with Nazism such as Sir <a href="Lewis%20Bernstein%20Namier">Lewis Bernstein Namier</a>, <a href="William%20L.%20Shirer">William L. Shirer</a>, <a href="A.J.P.%20Taylor">A.J.P. Taylor</a> and Sir <a href="John%20Wheeler-Bennett">John Wheeler-Bennett</a>. Moreover, far from Nazism being rooted in German traditions, Rothfels claimed that the strongest opposition to Nazism came from those grounded in traditional values. In Rothfels's opinion, "the traditions of a genuine 'Prussian militarism'" provided the principle "bulwark against nationalistic and demagogic excesses". "The German Opposition to Hitler" ended with a call for people all over the West to embrace what Rothfels regarded as the noble ideas of the conservative opponents of Nazism, which Rothfels saw as leading to back to the higher values of the West.
"The German Opposition To Hitler" was a controversial book because Rothfels focused his attention largely on anti-Nazis on the Right and for the most part ignored anti-Nazis on the Left. In addition, many felt that the book was a hagiographical treatment of anti-Nazi conservatives. His motive in writing the book was in part to prevent the emergence of a new stab-in-the-back legend that might once again undermine democracy in Germany. He was dismayed by public opinion polls taken immediately after <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> in the American zone of occupation that showed the majority of Germans had a low opinion of the men and women involved in the 20 July plot. Rothfels was determined that Germans should see them as heroes, not villains.
Return to Germany.
In 1951, Rothfels returned to <a href="West%20Germany">West Germany</a>, where he taught at the <a href="University%20of%20T%C3%BCbingen">University of Tübingen</a>. He worked hard for the rest of his life to exonerate German nationalism from the taint of Nazism. Upon his return to Germany, Rothfels founded the "<a href="Institut%20f%C3%BCr%20Zeitgeschichte">Institut für Zeitgeschichte</a>" (Institute for Contemporary History), an historical study center devoted to the Nazi period. The institute's journal, the "Vierteljahrshefte für Zeitgeschichte" (Journal for Contemporary History) has become one of the world's leading periodicals for the study of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>. Within a few years, the "Vierteljahrshefte für Zeitgeschichte" had the highest circulation of any historical journal in West Germany. During the 1950s, Rothfels was one of the few German historians who attempted a serious examination of <a href="the%20Holocaust">the Holocaust</a>, which was a subject that most German historians preferred to ignore during that decade. In particular, he broke new ground by publishing <a href="Kurt%20Gerstein">Kurt Gerstein</a>'s reports relating to the Final Solution in the first edition of the "Vierteljahrshefte für Zeitgeschichte" in 1953 and another article in 1959 that examined the plight of Polish Jewry under Nazi rule.
In his works Rothfels aimed at minimising the German hostility to Jews, while highlighting any attempts to save them by German individuals. Crimes and support for anti-semitism were downplayed, and opposition to racial discrimination portrayed by Rothfels as dominant. As such his text produced a vision of history in which for example the 1930s were virtually absent from anti-semitism, and non-Jewish Germans were completely willing to help Jews.
After his return to Germany, Rothfels was a pioneer of contemporary history, the study of the "epoch of those who lived at the time" to use Rothfels's words. In Rothfels's view, contemporary history was the study of the recent past, where despite or rather because the lack of documentation caused by studying events so close to the past and the challenge of writing about events that one experienced oneself, required special patience, skill and ability of the part of the historian. In particular, Rothfels called for historians working in the field of contemporary history to approach matters in an objective and neutral matter while keeping in mind the moral questions. In practice, contemporary history came to refer history from 1914 on.
After his return to Germany, Rothfels took a strong stand against those whose work he felt could exonerate the Nazis. In 1954, he and one of his star pupils from the University of Chicago, <a href="Gerhard%20Weinberg">Gerhard Weinberg</a> had a renowned debate on the pages of "Vierteljahrshefte für Zeitgeschichte" with <a href="Andreas%20Hillgruber">Andreas Hillgruber</a> and Hans-Günther Seraphim over the issue of whether the German <a href="Operation%20Barbarossa">invasion of the Soviet Union</a> in 1941 had been a "preventive war" forced on <a href="Adolf%20Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a> by the possibility of Soviet attack on Germany. Hillgruber and Seraphim argued for the "preventive war" thesis while Rothfels and Weinberg opposed it, arguing that it was Nazi racial theories that were the origins of the German invasion of the Soviet Union. The majority opinion was that Rothfels and Weinberg destroyed Seraphim's and Hillgruber's arguments. Indeed, Hillgruber himself did a volte-face and renounced his former thesis as mistaken. Later, in 1961, Rothfels took a strong stand against the American <a href="neo-Nazi">neo-Nazi</a> historian <a href="David%20Hoggan">David Hoggan</a> who claimed that the outbreak of war in 1939 had been due to an <a href="United%20Kingdom">Anglo</a>-<a href="Poland">Polish</a> conspiracy against Germany. Also in 1961, Rothfels assisted Weinberg with the publication of <a href="Adolf%20Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a>'s "<a href="Zweites%20Buch">Zweites Buch</a>" which Weinberg had discovered in 1958, and for which Rothfels wrote the introduction.
Another area of interest for Rothfels was the <a href="Expulsion%20of%20Germans%20after%20World%20War%20II">expulsion</a> of the ethnic German population from <a href="Eastern%20Europe">Eastern Europe</a> after <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. In the 1950s, Rothfels worked with <a href="Theodor%20Schieder">Theodor Schieder</a>, <a href="Werner%20Conze">Werner Conze</a> and other historians to produce the multi-volume "Documentation of the Expulsion of Germans from East Central Europe". Many later prominent historians such as <a href="Martin%20Broszat">Martin Broszat</a>, <a href="Hans-Ulrich%20Wehler">Hans-Ulrich Wehler</a> and <a href="Hans%20Mommsen">Hans Mommsen</a> were involved in this project.
Controversy.
In his lifetime and since his death, Rothfels has been a very controversial figure. Many see him as apologist for the anti-democratic German Right, and in particular, his attitude towards the Weimar Republic has recently been the subject of controversy in Germany. The historian <a href="Ingo%20Haar">Ingo Haar</a> in his 2000 book "Historiker im Nationalsozialismus" called Rothfels an enemy of the <a href="Weimar%20Republic">Weimar Republic</a> and a <a href="Nazi%20sympathizer">Nazi sympathizer</a>. The historian <a href="Heinrich%20August%20Winkler">Heinrich August Winkler</a> has strongly criticized Haar, who had erroneously used a <a href="radio">radio</a> address Rothfels gave in 1930 praising <a href="Friedrich%20Ebert">Friedrich Ebert</a>, <a href="Gustav%20Stresemann">Gustav Stresemann</a>, and <a href="Paul%20von%20Hindenburg">Paul von Hindenburg</a> as great German leaders as a proof for Rothfels' support of Hitler. While Haar had implied the speech dates from 1933 and was addressed to Hitler after he took over power in Germany, Winkler verified the actual circumstances of the speech, which Rothfels repeated several times prior to 1933. Rothfels's critics contend that his planned 1933 radio address was too little, too late.
Rothfels and his inner circle at Königsberg in the early 1930s are often referred to as the "Königsberg circle" (). Its most prominent members, apart from Rothfels himself, were his students <a href="Theodor%20Schieder">Theodor Schieder</a> and <a href="Werner%20Conze">Werner Conze</a>. Whereas Rothfels had to emigrate, Schieder and Conze joined the <a href="Nazi%20Party">NSDAP</a>. They were active in the field of <a href="Ostforschung">Ostforschung</a>, where they supported ideas such as 'dejewfication' (). After Rothfels' return the three became leading figures among the historians of the newly founded <a href="West%20Germany">West Germany</a>. They soon found themselves together in a <a href="Schieder%20commission">commission led by Schieder</a> that was set up by the government for documenting the <a href="expulsion%20of%20Germans%20after%20World%20War%20II">expulsion of Germans after World War II</a>.
In 1998 the 42nd "Deutscher Historikertag" marked the beginning of a public debate among German historians about the "brown history" of their field.
